title: Ethereum: Truffle + Meteor
content: Ethereum: Truffle + MeteorRob MyersFollowJan 27, 2016 · 3 min readMeteor is the recommended development framework for Ethereum dApps. Truffle is Consensys’ development system for Ethereum dApps. We cannot currently add a Meteor build phase to Truffle, but we can integrate them easily enough with a script.Install Meteor, Truffle and testrpc:curl https://install.meteor.com/ | shsudo npm install -g trufflesudo npm install -g ethereumjs-testrpcThen create a file called truffle-meteor-build, in ~/bin or somewhere else easily accessible and paste the following into it:#!/bin/bash# By Rob Myers <rob@robmyers.org># CC0 2016# To the extent possible under law, the person who associated CC0 with this# work has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this work.# We copy the .meteor/ dir from app/ into the specified environment's build/ dir# then call meteor-build-client in there, building into a meteor/ directory# next to build/ .if [ "${1}" = "-h" ] || [ "${1}" = "--help" ]then    echo "Usage: truffle-meteor-build [environment]"    echo "       Copies the .meteor directory from app into the truffle build,"    echo "       then calls meteor-build-client."    echo "ARGS:  [environment] - The truffle environment to use (default developmpment)."    echo "       Make sure you have npm install -g meteor-build-client"    echo "       and meteor init in the truffle app/ directory."fienvironment="${1:-development}"base_dir="$(pwd)"if [ ! -f "${base_dir}/truffle.json" ]then    echo "Please call from within the top level of a Truffle project."    exit 1fiapp_dir="${base_dir}/app"dot_metoer_dir="${app_dir}/.meteor"environment_dir="${base_dir}/environments/${environment}"truffle_build_dir="${environment_dir}/build"meteor_build_dir="${environment_dir}/meteor"if [ ! -d "${environment_dir}" ]then    echo "Cannot find directory for environment ${environment}."    exit 1fipushd "${base_dir}" > /dev/nullecho "Truffle: building ${environment} in ${truffle_build_dir}"truffle build "${environment}"cp -r "${app_dir}/.meteor" "${truffle_build_dir}"pushd "${truffle_build_dir}" > /dev/nullecho "Meteor: building client in ${meteor_build_dir}"meteor-build-client "${meteor_build_dir}" -p ''popd > /dev/nullpopd > /dev/nullAnd make it executable:chmod +x truffle-meteor buildIn one shell window start testrpc:testrpcIn another shell window create the Truffle/Meteor project:mkdir truffle-meteortruffle initcd truffle-meteorcd apprm -rf *meteor create .meteor add ethereum:elementsThis will create files called app.html, app.js, and app.css . You can rename them to whatever you like. Open truffle-meteor/truffle.json in a text editor and make sure the filenames match those in app/, that the Javascript file has the requisite post-processing commands to add Truffle and the Contract code and that there are no post-process commands for the HTML files.The results should look similar to this:{  "build": {    "is-art.html": {      "files": [        "is-art.html"      ],      "post-process": []    },    "is-art.js": {      "files": [      "is-art.js"      ],      "post-process": [        "bootstrap",        "frontend-dependencies"      ]    },    "app.css": [      "is-art.css"    ],    "images/": "images/"  },  "deploy": [    "IsArt"  ],  "rpc": {    "host": "localhost",    "port": 8545  }}Edit the contract, HTML, CSS and JavaScript as needed.Deploy the contract:truffle deployThen build the meteor project:truffle-meteor-buildYou can now open the Meteor client in a web browser:chromium environments/development/meteor/index.htmlAs you continue to develop the project you can reload the Meteor client in the web browser to see your changes. Make sure you keep testrpc running — if you stop and restart it you’ll need to deploy the contracts again.Originally published at robmyers.org on January 27, 2016.

title: Build your Ethereum DApp on Windows with Truffle, Ganache and Metamask (Beginners Guide)
content:
Build your Ethereum DApp on Windows with Truffle, Ganache and Metamask (Beginners Guide)Filza TariqFollowAug 28 · 8 min readIn this tutorial I am going to show you that how simply you can develop an ethereum dapp from scratch using Truffle, Metamask and Ganache. To setup your system with necessary dependencies refer to my previous article and setup your system to begin developing your first dapp.Before we dive into the development, let me give you an overview about the architecture of Ethereum Dapp we are going to develop and how different puzzles are going to fit into the picture. So let’s start the journey to build your Ethereum DApp.What are Ethereum Dapps?Dapps are the decentralized applications that runs on a peer-to-peer network unlike traditional web apps that runs on centralized servers. When these dapps are built over ethereum network, these are known as “ethereum dapps”. In decentralized apps, all the users’ data is stored on immutable distributed ledger and every participating nodes have a copy of that ledger. These dapps logic that runs on the blockchain nodes is written in solidity language and traditionally called as “smart contracts”.Architecture of our Ethereum Dapp:Client’s Browser: It is just like a normal browser of any web application written in html, css and javascript.Web3.js: Web3.js is a collection of libraries that enables your browser to interact with blockchain. It enables you to read and write data from smart contracts, transfer ethers between accounts and much more.Web3 Provider: Ethereum network contains nodes and all nodes share the same copy of data. Setting a “web3 provider” in web3.js tells our code that which node we are going to read and write data from. We are using Metamask in our implementation that injects its web3 provider in the browser. Metamask is a browser extension for Chrome and Firefox that lets users securely manage their Ethereum accounts and private keys, and use these accounts to interact with websites that are using Web3.js.Ethereum Virtual Machine: Every ethereum node in ethereum network runs their own EVM implementation and responsible for running the same instructions of smart contracts over the ethereum network.Ok that’s all about the theory, to wake you up let’s start with the development.What we are going to develop?We are going to develop a simple decentralized newsfeed system. News publisher can post news on blockchain with their account addresses. These news will be immutable and displayed in the same order as they are posted.Our Final Dapp will look something like this:You can refer to the code at GitHub anytime you face issues. But I urge you to code each step yourself along with me.Step 1: Setting up the StructureI presume that you have set the development environment already. In command prompt create a new directory and unbox “truffle-box” in that respective directory to get the structure of project.mkdir postnewscd postnewstruffle unbox pet-shopThis will set up the following basic structure in your folder:Let’s examine the project structure Truffle Box gave us.Contracts: As obvious with the name, here all our smart contracts will reside.Migrations: Includes Migration files to migrate smart contracts to blockchain.Node_modules: Contains all node dependenciesSrc: Home for all client side application codeTest: Where we write tests for our smart contract either in solidity or javascript. We are not going to write any tests in our implementation because we are building a basic implementation of Dapp. But tests are important to write when you are working on commercial projects, because each migration of smart contract on blockchain causes gas cost. Thus, you want to make sure that your smart contracts are bug free and perform the intended functionality.Step 2: Writing Smart ContractCreate a new file news.sol in contract folder and write the following code in it.pragma solidity >=0.4.0 <=0.6.0;contract news{struct newsfeed{address publisher;string newsdesc;}mapping(uint => newsfeed) public newsfeeds;uint public newsCount;function addnews(string memory newsdesc) public {newsCount++;newsfeeds[newsCount].publisher = msg.sender;newsfeeds[newsCount].newsdesc = newsdesc;}}Let me explain this code. First we specify that the current code is runnable on the solidity compiler version greater than 0.4.0 and smaller than 0.6.0 with “pragma solidity”. Then we initialized the contract and initialized the structure of our newsfeed containing address of publisher (initialized with address data type) and news itself (initialized with string data type).To store this created structure we have created mapping that is just like a key value pair. The key to mapping is an unsigned integer and the value is the “newsfeed struct”.“newscount” keeps track of the number of posted news and initially 0. Addnews function will store publisher address and news in the struct referenced by the key value. “msg.sender” gets the address of account which has called the contract.Simple. Isn’t it? Now let’s compile this smart contract to see if it runs properly. To do this, navigate to your project folder in console and writetruffle compileNow lets migrate our current smart contract on Ganache. To do this, create a new file in Migration folder named “2_deploy_contracts.js”. Paste the following code in that file to migrate your contract:var news = artifacts.require(“./news.sol”);module.exports = function(deployer) {deployer.deploy(news);};Save it and in console type:truffle migrateMake sure that Ganache is open and running while you migrate your contract. And hurrah! Your contract is successfully migrated to Ganache.Step 3: Developing Client-side application to interact with contractGo to your index.html file and paste the following code:Decentralized Newsfeed

Decentralized Newsfeed


Add Product →Add News
Add News
Publisher Address

Account Address

Descrition:
Ok! Don’t scare yourself it’s just some simple html. Let me go through it. Add News Button is navigating to the model that opens a dialogue for adding news. “posttemplate” contains the layout of how your posts will be displayed on screen.To make this code in action lets write some code in app.js and see how it is going to link up with our smart contract.In your app.js file first add the following code to setup the web3 provider for web3.js in browser.App = {web3Provider: null,contracts: {},initWeb3: async function() {// Modern dapp browsers…if (window.ethereum) {App.web3Provider = window.ethereum;try {// Request account accessawait window.ethereum.enable();} catch (error) {// User denied account access…console.error(“User denied account access”)}}// Legacy dapp browsers…else if (window.web3) {App.web3Provider = window.web3.currentProvider;}// If no injected web3 instance is detected, fall back to Ganacheelse {App.web3Provider = new Web3.providers.HttpProvider(‘http://localhost:7545');}// App.web3Provider = new Web3.providers.HttpProvider(‘http://localhost:8545');web3 = new Web3(App.web3Provider);return App.initContract();},Extend app.js with the following code:initContract: function() {$.getJSON(‘news.json’, function(data) {// Get the necessary contract artifact file and instantiate it with truffle-contractApp.contracts.news = TruffleContract(data);// Set the provider for our contractApp.contracts.news.setProvider(App.web3Provider);return App.init();});return App.AddNewsButton();},When we compile our contract “news.json” is created in build folder. Truffle has a library called “TruffleContract” that keeps information about the contract. So using this library we set web3 provider for our contract. This enables our client side application to interact with our smart contract deployed on blockchain.Move forward and add the following code in app.js:AddNewsButton: function() {$(document).on(‘click’, ‘.addNews’, App.AddNews);},AddNews:function(event){var post = document.getElementById(‘post’).valuevar postInstance;App.contracts.news.deployed().then(function(instance){postInstance = instance;return postInstance.addnews(post);});console.log(“News posted”);},};This code will take the user entered news and pass it to our add news function in smart contract. Smart contract will write the publisher address and news on blockchain using mapping.Finally add the following code in app.js to render the html template with data on every page reload so your news will be displayed.init: async function() {// Load Newsvar postInstance;App.contracts.news.deployed().then(function(instance){postInstance = instance;return postInstance.newsCount();}).then(function(result){var counts = result.c[0];console.log(“Total News : “+counts);for (var i = 1; i <= counts; i ++) {postInstance.newsfeeds(i).then(function(result){console.log(“Publisher Address:” +result[0]);console.log(“News:” +result[1]);var newsRow = $(‘#newsRow’);var postTemplate = $(‘#postTemplate’);postTemplate.find(‘.panel-title’).text(result[0]);postTemplate.find(‘.desc’).text(result[1]);newsRow.append(postTemplate.html());});}});‘i’ initialized with 1 is passed as a key to newsfeeds mapping. This will fetch the structure details on index i. Structure details are just like an array having “publisher address” at 0 index and “newsdesc” at 1 index. This data will be retrieved from smart contract and append to “postTemplate” in index.html.Now in your console type “npm run dev” to run your dapp.This will open up the dapp in your browser. Make sure you are logged in with metamask and its running on port 7545.Kudos! You have successfully developed your Dapp. Happy Coding!

Claire RussoFollowJan 13, 2016 · 4 min readLife Lessons of the Truffle: Self Indulgence vs. Receiving JoyA black winter truffle. Not as precious as a white Alba truffle, but still delicious! Image my own.Lila, the lean hound, zigzagged across our path in the misty hazelnut grove, her nose to the ground. Suddenly, as if she’d heard her name called, she dashed to the foot of a nearby tree and began digging, paws blurring and earth flying through the air.“Lila! Dai!” Her handler dragged her back, stroking and praising her, while we hurried to kneel at Lila’s paws. He handed us our tools: a short spade and a vanghetto — a kind of slender miniature axe, with one blunt end and one pronged.“Be very gentle,” he warned. Carefully, we went to work. Lila had already revealed the outlines of what we sought: an earth-colored knob small enough to be cradled in the palm of your hand. We detached it from the soil — brushing as much earth off the sides as we could, seeding the find for next year’s harvest — and held it up to our noses, greedily inhaling the heady aroma. We had found one: a precious white Alba truffle.Alba, a town in Piedmont, northern Italy, is known for its hazelnuts (the majority of the harvest from the grove we were hunting in would be sold to Nutella), its delicious nebbiolo wines (the best known examples are the Barolo and Barbaresco), and most famously, its fabulously aromatic and potent white truffles. White Alba truffles are among the most valuable in the world — they have been priced up to $10,000 per pound. We had come from London to spend a weekend at the International Truffle Festival, which runs in Alba for 6 weeks in October and November every year.I expected to enjoy some terrific food while we were in Alba that weekend. And we did — crispy fried eggs topped with shaved truffle, fresh buttered spaghetti with truffle, even silky vanilla gelato piled with translucent curls of delicate truffle. It was even more fabulous than I had imagined. The whole town was pervaded by that joyous, contented buzz that one feels after pushing back from the table and loosening the top button of your jeans after a really fantastic meal.Because another reason truffles are so precious is that they don’t have a long shelf life. Once they are taken from the ground, they are best eaten right away — or three to five days later, at the most. There we were, in the center of a culinary capital, surrounded by rare, delicious food that we were obliged to eat right away. I’m happy to report that everyone rose to the occasion. There was something wonderful about seeing a whole town tuck in to such precious delicacies without a smidgen of guilt. (Not that Italians ever evince much guilt around enjoying themselves, especially when it comes to food. I should know — I’m married to an Italian.)The thing was, it didn’t feel like self-indulgence, this massive truffle-fest. Don’t get me wrong, it was indulgent to fly to Alba for a weekend of eating wonderful food, but I wouldn’t say it was self-indulgent. Does that feel like I’m splitting hairs? Self-indulgence is, to me, mindlessly eating an entire bag of salt and vinegar crisps on the couch, is binge-watching the latest Netflix series in a single weekend, is the flat, empty, alcoholic buzz on a Monday night, is blankly watching pornography in the dark. What I experienced in Alba that weekend, on the other hand, felt like something entirely different. It didn’t feel like we were being self-indulgent at all. It felt like we were receiving.Receiving is not self-indulgent. Receiving is whole-heartedly accepting the good, the beautiful, the joyous aspects and moments of our lives. Where self-indulgence is oddly passive, receiving is active. Where self-indulgence is absent, receiving is present. In fact, we absolutely must be fully present, fully in the moment, to receive at all, because it is necessarily a fleeting experience. It is therefore vulnerable and very raw and somehow pure. It’s joyful. Even if it’s only eating a plate of simple spaghetti, and relishing every perfect al dente bite.We are inclined, I think, to think of joy like a fine wine — something to be kept out of direct sunlight, in a climate-controlled space where it won’t get jostled, to be taken out reverently and enjoyed only “on a special occasion.” Why is this? Could it be that we are afraid of joy? There is a kind of peculiar paranoia here — as if we think that the second we let joy in, someone or something will snatch it away. Or as if we’re only allotted a small modicum of joy each, to be carefully rationed out over the course of a lifetime. Of course, taking a step back, this is blatantly illogical: the only person we deprive by rejecting joy — in whatever form it appears to us — is ourselves.Since our weekend trip to Alba, I’m inclined to think of joy less like a fine wine and more like a truffle. When I scent it across my path, I intend to race to get my hands dirty digging it up, and then I intend to devour it — infuse my morning eggs with it, and my lunchtime pasta, and my evening ice cream. I intend to gorge myself on joy, when I find it, wherever I find it. Because I know that those moments will sustain me through the dark months when the Alba truffle is out of season, slowly re-growing in the damp, warm womb of the hazelnut groves.

title: Truffle Hunt Club
content: Truffle Hunt ClubTruffleFollowJun 14, 2017 · 2 min readWe hosted our first Truffle Hunt Club event on Wednesday June 7th at Sunday in Brooklyn. It was a magical evening with friends.The tasting menu from Sunday in Brooklyn adorned with a Truffle Hunt Club pendantEver since Truffle launched for iPhone back in November, we’ve been gearing up for the second phase of our mission, which is to get our friends together in real life. For the first event, we went all out. Guests at Sunday in Brooklyn were led up a secret entrance to the cocktail reception on the patio, where we strung a 3D printed metal pendant on them to commemorate their joining the Truffle Hunt Club.The guests adjourned to the private dining room to hear Adam Landsman explain why he started Sunday in Brooklyn and about the sustainable, multi-course tasting menu that we were about to enjoy.Radishes sliced thin with Koji butter served on an amaranth crackerCourses arrived, and the entertainment began. There was stand-up comedy and music, all beautifully photographed and assiduously shared so guests didn’t have to split their attention and capture the memories they were making. On that note, we’d like to send out a huge thanks to Chris Duffy, Luisa Bastidas, Suni Reyes, Anna Bouma and Molly Sonsteng for making it an evening worth remembering for all 50+ of us.Chris Duffy raising his handsThat was the first Truffle Hunt Club. The spirit of Truffle is to celebrate the many ways we can bring people together over food. The goal of the first event was to realize our dream, dinner gathering.Be on the lookout for the next Truffle Hunt Club! The next one will dispense with the tickets and all of the extras. Instead, the second Hunt will be an affordable excursion where we can all channel our inner Bourdain.Not part of the Truffle community yet? Tap here to join

title: Solidity 0.5.6, Trustless Exchanges, Infura Competitor and Truffle 5.0.8
content: Solidity 0.5.6, Trustless Exchanges, Infura Competitor and Truffle 5.0.8Blockchain Dev Weekly Digest 18.03.19George SpasovFollowMar 18 · 4 min readHello everyone and welcome to my favourite time of the week — the one where we review the note-worthy dev news from the past 7 days.Today we take a look at afew bugfix updates, a new tool for reviewing the flow of transactions, the emerging Infura competitor and lastly — an article reviewing the architecturing of trustless non-custodial exchange.Languages, Tools and Libraries updatesSolidity 0.5.6 ReleasedResource: https://github.com/ethereum/solidity/releases/tag/v0.5.6The Solidity team has been on fire lately and after treating us to an update last week, we’ve been surprised with a new Solidity update for this one too.Solidity 0.5.6 was released as a bugfix release to an optimiser bug in 0.5.5, which resulted in overflows when using certain operations. Although probably no contracts have been exposed to it, the Solidity team urges everyone to move to 0.5.6 asap. In addition, there are further advancements in the SMTChecker and AbiEncoder v2.For the contents of the previous release check the previous episode here:Solidity 0.5.5, Opera to add iOS wallets and libraries updatesBlockchain Dev Weekly Digest 11.03.19medium.comTruffle 5.0.8 ReleasedResource: https://github.com/trufflesuite/truffle/releases/tag/v5.0.8Truffle has released a new version of their framework — 5.0.8. This version comes with several fixes and improvements on the framework. The most notable change is on the improved support of vyper contracts and their unit-testing usability.Libraries, Tools, InfrastructureTxFlow — Trace your transaction flow inside and between contractsResource: https://github.com/Tenderly/ethparis-txflowOne of the most exciting tools coming out of ETHParis is called TxFlow, developed by the awesome team at Tenderly. TxFlow allows you to trace the flow of a transaction inside and outside of contracts.By simply inputing your transaction hash of the transaction you want to trace, you are able to see the stack of executions in an aesthetic, visual way. I do hope we are going to see more of this tool in the next months.As far as I’ve seen, it might require a certain modification of the geth node, but hopefully this can be made to work with a regular released geth and parity.Nodesmith Ethereum betaResource: https://medium.com/nodesmith-blog/announcing-the-nodesmith-ethereum-beta-eab286d5075dOn the matter of nodes, a new player has emerged at the infrastructure as a service scene to compete with Infura.The company is called Nodesmith and they have released their beta version of their tool, with support for Ethereum (except Mainnet, though).Nodesmith, as expected, support and handle Ethereum JSON RPC calls like any node. In addition, they have an exciting feature of event caching — feature that I’ve seen multiple projects being forced to implement themselves. Another exciting claim is that their architecture is supposed to be cloud provider agnostic, with tons of engineering put behind to make it true.Exciting things that they’ve planned ahead are:IPFS node as a serviceWebhooks APIHosted side-chains and bridgesTutorials & ArticlesTrustless, Noncustodial Exchange PrototypeResource: https://blog.enuma.io/update/2019/03/08/trustless-noncustodial-exchange.htmlLast but not least, a new exciting read by enuma.io has been published. The topic at hand is an overview of how one can create trustless non-custodial exchanges.The gist of it is creating a plasma-like layer 2 solution. The operator serves and maintains the balances of the users while committing to a Merkle Tree root of the balances they maintain. The clients are required to log in at least once a day in order to verify and dispute if needed.Such an architecture provides both security and performance to the system. The tradeoff comes in the liveness requirement for the users of this system.Follow us on:https://twitter.com/GSpasovhttps://twitter.com/LimeChainHQhttps://twitter.com/etherlimehttps://limechain.tech/Sources:Latest Week in EthereumThe latest Week in Ethereum News is: https://weekinethereumnews.com/february-8-2019/www.weekinethereum.comr/ethdevr/ethdev: Ethereum-related dev talk: Contracts, DApps, Wallets, Clients, Infrastructure, Tooling, UIs, Patterns, and…www.reddit.comThanks to all the people that have messaged me about the news this week!About the author: George Spasov, Co-founder and Blockchain Architect @LimeChain, has developed a multitude of blockchain projects — public and private — and is a prominent member of several blockchains communities. He is most recognized for his work on Etherlime — the ECF and ETHPrize ethers.js-based development and deployment framework, LimePay — the UX solution for executing blockchain transactions with a credit card and being one of the first members of the MetaCartel — the meta-transactions community.

title: “Truffle compile” so slow — solc is much faster
content: “Truffle compile” so slow — solc is much fasterViktor NosovFollowAug 31, 2017 · 1 min readTruffle compile speedWhen we use truffle framework and compile ethereum solidity smart contracts with “truffle compile” command, actually we use javascript version of solidity compiler. But solidity compiler works very slow, for instance compiling of ~20 .sol files takes about 2 minutes.Simple solution is to use solc binary package, that works much faster. You can install this package by commands:sudo add-apt-repository ppa:ethereum/ethereumsudo apt-get updatesudo apt-get install solcBut next, we must dump compiled EVM bytecode to truffle build files, located in build/contract folder. We can do this by simple javascript script:Now compilation of the same files takes only 10s ( vs 96s using javascript solidity compiler)https://github.com/vitiko/truffle-fast-compile — command line utility for compiling solidity contracts via solc binary package

title: How to test smart contracts using Truffle for thousands of transactions
content: How to test smart contracts using Truffle for thousands of transactionsIntroductionAndrey VolkovFollowJan 31, 2018 · 3 min readDeveloping and especially testing smart contracts are not an easy task. In case when they have a complex business logic it becomes much harder.Recently I needed to test a smart contract for thousands of participants and check how much gas the contract needs for its methods. It was necessary to prove robustness of business logic and predictability of costs. I spent a few days on testing and I found a pretty fast way for heavy load testing in local blockchain net.PrerequisitesI assume that you know the basics about smart contracts, Ethereum, Truffle framework and Ganache (ex. TestRPC).Versions:Truffle 4.0.3Ganache-cli v6.1.0-beta.0 (see this release notes) I had to use this beta version, because the latest stable release 6.0.3 had permanent issue with “gasPrice of undefined”web3js 0.20.2Be aware that web3js 1.0 has completely different API than version 0.20.x and this article may be obsolete in a month or so. Gears are spinning, chains are moving.Demo projectThere is the demo project for this article: https://github.com/Kipriz/truffle-heavy-loadIt contains a simple smart contract, a kind of dummy lottery, and the tests for it that can operate with thousands of transactions and participants.Automining approach: limited number of txsInitially, I tried the most straigthforward and dummy way: run ganache-cli with automining and execute transactions one by one. See this test for reference.This approach was pretty fast, about 500 txs in 50 seconds. If a test waits for events, it took much longer, about 1 tx/s.However, when I tried 5000 txs, truffle was not able to wait or understand what happens and it fails: Error: Could not connect to your Ethereum client. Please check that your Ethereum clientI was wondering a way to test at least 15K txs and automining did not work. I tried to combine transaction in blocks per 100 and add delays between the blocks. It worked, but was unstable and slow. I needed to set delay with a margin to be sure than 100 txs had been proceeded. Then I tried to disable automining and set fixed block time…Fixed blocktime and events: unlimited number of txs if you have enough patienceFirstly, I discovered than I can specify block time and disable automining. I run ganache-cli in the following way:> ganache-cli -m "candy maple cake sugar pudding cream honey rich smooth crumble sweet treat" -u 0 -u 1 --gasLimit 0x2FEFD800000 -a 100 --defaultBalanceEther 10000 --blocktime 5 > ganache.logA few useful comments:--blocktime 5 — set block time to 5 seconds.-a 100 — number of accounts to create. Ganache UI allows up to 100 accounts, CLI is able to operate with 10K.--defaultBalanceEther 10000 — feel free to allocate as much ether to accounts as you need. It is just free in your local test net--gasLimit 0x2FEFD800000 — use it to avoid permanent ‘out of gas’ exceptions. However, be careful with gas usage.Initially, I tried to submit a bunch of transaction, wait 10 to 15 seconds and than submit another bunch. It worked but not better than automining and again I needed to wait some extra time.Secondly, I found that I can subscribe to ‘block mined’ event and not wait extra time. Ethereum allows to subscribe for 2 events: pending and latest. The names are slightly cryptic, but pending event occurs when there is at least 1 pending transaction for next block. The latest event is fired after mining of a block.Subscribe for latest event to do something after a block is mined. For example, send next bunch of transactions.See this test for all details: https://github.com/Kipriz/truffle-heavy-load/blob/master/test/Test_03_buy_500_tickets_using_events.es6This test can be run with 5K txs or even 15K. I’m sure than it can bear even more, but I did not have enough patience.Now, you can test thousands of transactions for your smart contract as fast as I know.

title: Behind the scenes of that favourite “truffle beef bowl” — a UX case study
content: Behind the scenes of that favourite “truffle beef bowl” — a UX case studyFoodRazor’s Website Redesigned.Michelle BridgetFollowSep 21, 2018 · 9 min readWhat goes beyond the secret recipe of your favourite dish? Rarely does the process of ordering supplies or handling invoices, or even choosing the better supplier comes to mind. Do we ever wonder what procedures the business goes through before that sizzling beef bowl reaches the table? I definitely didn’t.At least, not until now.Disclaimer: This is a pro bono collaboration with FoodRazor for our final project at UXDI General Assembly, Singapore.The ask was to redesign the layout of FoodRazor’s website based on user research and translate actionable insights into workable solutions for their new site.As this was our first back-stage pass to the F&B industry, we were eager to explore every corner and turn every stone for this 3-week sprint!Phase One: Understanding the BusinessWhat/Who is FoodRazor?FoodRazor is a food procurement software for restaurants to manage their orders and supplies, extract data from invoices and review personalised analytics to grow their business.Their goal for the website is for it to act as a spokesperson for the business, and have sufficient information to attend to any burning enquiries from potential customers. When you trim relayed communication, it speeds up the decision making process, in the hopes to increase the number of sign ups.We kickstarted the project with a heuristic evaluation to identify usability issues with the user interface (UI) design of the site.What was done well?The overall design of the website was clean and simple. The use of white space created a visual hierarchy and it directed the focus on the content.The “sticky” navigation bar allows ease of access to the website’s core functionalities.The current websiteWhat needed improvement?Consecutive automated carousel sliders were too distracting and confusing.Language used on the website was too technical.Overloading of information resulted in heavy cognitive load for the user.Competitor Research AnalysisWe also conducted competitive analysis to see how competitors, ZeeMart (local) and MarketMan (international), have fared with their website and how FoodRazor could learn from them. The analysis was done with the LEMErS framework, where 5 is the highest score.GIF — Competitive analysis assessing the site based on 5 criteria (LEMErS framework)Phase Two: Understanding the UsersTo see things from the flip side, we ran interviews with key project stakeholders, potential customers and existing users.Stakeholder InterviewsThe goal of interviewing the Sales and Customer Success teams was to help inform our understanding of their existing customer base, outreach processes and on-boarding sessions with potential customers.Key FindingsCustomers are driven by value.Customers are concerned with how to use the software, how will it benefit them and how it will integrate with their business.Affinity Map for Stakeholder InterviewsUser InterviewsThe scope was focused on customer usage profiling to understand the current technologies and processes that restaurant/cafe owners and chefs have adopted.Key FindingsUsers are hesitant to use new technology because of the learning curve.They have developed their own methods of doing the accounting as well as keeping track of orders.They communicate with their suppliers via WhatsApp or calls. Some have been working with the same supplier for many years.Those who have been in the industry for a long time are very comfortable with their current communication methods with suppliers.Affinity Map for User InterviewsHow did the current website fared for the users?We led usability tests with the interviewees to see what they took away from browsing the website for the first time.The display of clientele is a good selling point as it builds confidence.Case studies are not necessarily important to the users as they don’t have time to read.Homepage failed to convey who and what FoodRazor is, at a glance.Persona & Customer Journey Map (CJM)With all the research data and insights collected, we created 3 personas to represent the different types of users that might use FoodRazor.The CJMs were designed to highlight key interactions that the personas have with the product through storytelling. It conveys user goals, emotions, pain points and opportunities in which FoodRazor can tap in to bridge the gaps.First Persona: Max, 28, Business-Chef OwnerMax is open to using new technology in his work processes for greater efficiency but is concerned that his older staff might not be able to adapt to the change. He needs a way for his staff to see the value and benefits of new technology in order to convince them get on board with it.Max’s Customer Journey MapSecond Persona: Jolene, 54, Business OwnerJolene does not rely heavily on technology to run her business. She only uses Excel to track her accountings. Due to her low tech proficiency, Jolene is resistant to advanced technology. She needs to know that the new software will be as easy and simple to use as the current ones she is using.Jolene’s Customer Journey MapThird Persona: Kenny, 41, Head ChefAs the sole decision maker in the kitchen, Kenny has to ensure that logistics are handled well and supplies are always in stock to anticipate demand and prevent cancellation of menu. He needs to know what his options are when he troubleshoots.Kenny’s Customer Journey MapPhase Three: Prototyping and ValidatingBridging the gaps with Content StrategyA content strategy map was used to identify content gaps in the user’s journey when they interact with the website. This helped us to focus on developing content based on the persona’s intent.Our solution will bridge the following content gaps –Highlight what matters the most: Users care about making informed decisions but are unable to because information are either hidden, insufficient or unavailable.Spell out the benefits in detail: Users are already comfortable with their current work processes. So what are we going to say to earn their buy-in? How will FoodRazor help their business make more money?Give assurance: Users are hesitant because of the learning curve. So we need to build confidence. Assure them that the learning process is straightforward and that help will always be readily available.Validating the PrototypesMeasuring Task UsabilityThe Single Ease Question (SEQ) is a 7-point rating scale to assess how difficult users find a task (7 being “Very Easy”). This test provided us with insights at every round, as we were able to ask for their reasons behind each score, in order to keep reiterating our prototype. The average scores of 6 tests made up the final scores.SEQ Test ResultsEven though the SEQ test showed good results (which means we have all the pieces we need), something was still not right.Designing with a StoryWith our first few prototypes, we were struggling to figure out the best way to manage both user needs and business goals. The prototypes were either too focused on the users or targetted at the business.And then it hit me.UX is all about telling a story — through user research, ideation and even usability testing. Because stories create impact.With story-telling, the website will be able to connect with users at a deeper level while fulfilling its goal as a spokesperson for the business. It can also address the users’ needs and pain points, and illustrate how they might achieve their goals with FoodRazor.The new layout will be designed to take them on a journey where they face their fears, slay ferocious dragons and save the day with a magical sword. Somewhat.And there we have it — our design solutions for FoodRazor’s website revamp. With these, we hope that we’ve met the needs of the users and helped to bring the business a step closer to its goals. Here’s to a successful launch!Disclaimer: As this is just a mid-fi prototype, the copies may be subjected to change at the discretion of FoodRazor. All illustrations used are for visualisation purposes only.Illustration credit: Cami Dobrin and MitasAfter ThoughtsAs my first client project came to a close, I realised I’ve learnt so much about the people I designed for and the people I designed with. So here are some takeaways that struck a chord.The sweet spotFinding the right balance between business goals and user needs is something you will have to figure out for every project. And it becomes exceptionally important when it involves real world clients. Their goals and problems become as real as your user’s and you want to ensure that you satisfy both ends.So you start to ask yourself questions like “If I do this, its good for the user but is it good for the business too? What value does it bring?”. I guess the only way to know is to keep collaborating with them and get their two cents’ worth so they have a say in the final product too.There will always be two sides to a coinAs UX designers, I feel like our main purpose here on earth is to empathise. Empathising with your users, your clients, your teams; and the list just keeps growing. And with that empathy, we go a step further and do something meaningful with it.I became a designer because it’s not enough for me to theoretically make the world a better place. I needed to know how to do it and do it right, and it seems that having empathy is a good place to start.Someone once shared this and it stuck with me for a long time. Hopefully it will stick with you too.In social issues class today our professor held up a black book and he said “this book is red”. We were all “no” and he said “yes it is” and we were just all “that’s not right”. Then he turned it around and the back cover was red and he said “don’t tell somebody they’re wrong until you’ve seen things from their point of view.”Special thanks to FoodRazor for entrusting us with this opportunity. I hope our design solutions have left some sort of impact and supported your research team in some way. Looking forward to your official website revamp!Three cheers for my teammates Joyce and Charlene for conquering this sprint with me! (though, it honestly felt like we ran an entire marathon) ಥ‿ಥThanks for reading!

title: Praise the Italian truffle gods!
content: Praise the Italian truffle gods!Guac Magazine EditorsFollowNov 30, 2018 · 7 min readBracciano, Italyby: Stephanie Roh“5 minutes!” I cried out nervously. The lactic acid felt like fire in my legs and my lungs were struggling to find air — I was starting to feel like I couldn’t run any longer. Leave it to me to be perpetually late to everything. Even an expensive Airbnb truffle hunting experience in Italy that I had on my bucket list for years.“Almost there!” my friend Jeremy encouraged me as we spotted the finish line: Roma Tuscolana station. Out of breath, Jeremy dashed to the ticket machine while I frantically scanned the departures board for the correct platform of the train headed to Bracciano. “WHERE ARE WE GOING AGAIN?” Jeremy yelled out.Platform 4, got it. I ran over to the ticket machine and I jabbed the button for Bracciano. My heart was pounding — one minute left! What felt like a century later, the machine spit out our tickets and we were sprinting, again, to the platform. Praise the Italian truffle gods!! The train had not left. I wondered what these Italian commuters must’ve been thinking of these two heavily-breathing, disheveled Americans that just hopped on their train. We took our seats and let out a huge sigh of relief. This train would get us to Bracciano at exactly 9AM, the meeting time of our expedition with Matteo (our truffle aficionado of the day). If the train had left without us, the next one would’ve been 45 minutes later, making us miss the experience of a lifetime. I looked at our tickets and let out a laugh. 3 euros for an hour and 15-minute train ride! My god, I love this country!Since we had a late night yesterday (which explains the running), we thought the train ride would be the perfect time to catch up on sleep. But alas, the seats were too upright, and we could barely sleep without our heads nodding. Still sleepy, we finally arrived at Bracciano, a small lakeside town 30 kilometers northwest of Rome. Matteo had messaged me saying that he would be 5 minutes late to pick us up, so Jeremy and I thought it would be a good idea to grab a snack since we hadn’t eaten anything that morning. We walked into the nearest café and found that it was completely empty and had tacky purple wallpaper and furniture. We tried asking the owner for some croissants in our horrible Italian and with a whole lot of pointing. He put them on plates and said it would be 2 euros. Shoot. We didn’t have any cash and he did not take card. Well this is awkward. Again, in botched Italian, we asked where the nearest ATM was and said that we would come back. Using ambiguous hand gestures, he said “around the corner, a left, a right, then straight for a while, then another left.”At this point the 5 minutes had already passed, and Matteo was waiting for us at the station. Jeremy and I attempted to find this ATM with no luck. We even walked into another café and was told “no card, only cash.” We stubbornly accepted defeat and headed back to the station. On the way, the purple-café owner was standing outside awaiting our money and we awkwardly said that we did not find the ATM and shrugged our shoulders. What a start. Worn out, hungry, and awkward. But we wouldn’t let this ruin our day.We introduced ourselves to Matteo, a cheerful young man who had grown up in Bracciano and makes a living hosting truffle hunting tours and selling truffles to restaurants and stores. Joining us on this trip were 2 middle-aged American journalists from Brooklyn. We all climbed into Matteo’s FIAT and were driven to a forest in Monterano Natural Reserve. Immediately, my nose crinkled in disgust. What is that awful smell? I looked behind me to find three adorable dogs (one black spaniel named Wendy and two Lagotto Romagnolos, an all-white one named Giulietta and a brown and white one named Uzi) panting in the trunk. The wet dog smell instantly made me car sick, so I attempted not to breathe for the whole fifteen-minute ride. As the roads got narrower, curvier, and rougher, I kept bumping legs with the woman next to me.At last, we made it. Matteo opened the trunk letting the dogs out, and they excitedly starting sniffing everybody and everything. Before we set out into the woods, Matteo explained the biology of truffles, their symbiosis with the trees in the forest, and their importance to Italian cuisine. In short, they put that stuff on everything.The truffle dogs (from left to right): Giulietta, Uzi, and Wendy.Matteo explaining the biology of truffles with Wendy in his arm.Giulietta smiling for the camera.We followed the dogs into the woods, watching with anticipation as they found the scent of truffles underneath the ground and starting digging. Matteo would run over, slide the dog out of the way, and use a knife and shovel to unearth the truffles. He would pass them around for everyone to smell. It smelled like a thousand dollars of culinary gold. Every time a dog found a truffle, Matteo would give them a treat and vigorously pet them in celebration. Giulietta would accidentally get too excited and bite down into truffles she found, Wendy was in training and would get easily distracted, and Uzi was in retirement and was just along for the ride. Every so often we would hear, “Giulietta, no! Uzi, dove sei? Wendy, qua!” It was an amusing chaos.Matteo digging through the soil for truffles.Giulietta proud of her latest find.I quickly fell in love with the Italian countryside. I had never seen so many beautiful wildflowers in one place. We picked some magenta sweet pea flowers and tucked them behind our ears. The views of Lake Bracciano and the rolling hills seemed alive with color and sound. There were even horses in the woods, making everything all the more majestic.Lake BraccianoMatteo hiking through the forest with horses hidden behind the trees.Sweet pea flowers tucked behind Jeremy’s ear.The diverse flora of the Italian countryside.“No!! Uzi!” Matteo jumped over a fence into the horse’s pen to retrieve Uzi who had rolled around in horse manure. Matteo dunked her repeatedly in the horse’s drinking water and let her go. We asked what happened and he replied, “She put her body into da poop-ah!” Deprived of food and sleep, me and Jeremy burst out laughing and couldn’t stop.After about two hours, Matteo’s pockets were full of truffles. He announced that it was time to go to his friend’s house in town for a homemade lunch con i tartufi. Finally! My stomach had been quivering with hunger pangs.We feasted on plate after plate of truffle-garnished pastas, cheeses, bread, eggs, and chickpeas with homemade wine and olive oil until we couldn’t stomach it anymore. Conversation was lovely for the first hour but then things began to drag on. Italians and Americans have very different attitudes towards awkward silences. Whenever we ran out of things to talk about, Matteo and his friend would smile and stare at us calmly. Us Americans fidgeted in our seats in discomfort and tried wrapping things up five separate times, “Well that was amazing . . . Matteo you are an excellent cook . . . I’m wiped out . . .” To this, Matteo thanked us and kept sitting. Eventually after another hour of uncomfortable off-and-on silence, we were back on the move.Homemade mozzarella with grated truffles.Matteo dropped us off at the train station, and we waved goodbye to our hospitable Italian host. “Want to go swimming?” I asked Jeremy. “Yeah, why not!” We walked down to the lake and splashed into the frigid water. Since Lake Bracciano used to be a volcano, the sand was black and extremely entertaining to play with. Floating in the water, I took a deep breath and tried to absorb the moment — I am swimming in Italy with my best friend! We smuggled some dinosaur bone-looking rocks and headed back to our Airbnb in Rome.A quick swim in Lake Bracciano at the end of a memorable day.While adventures off the beaten track are full of unexpected mishaps and awkward interactions, it is this imperfection that makes them so memorable. They are, without a doubt, experiences of a lifetime. And to think we almost missed our train.About the Writer:Stephanie is from Weehawken, New Jersey and her favorite city is Copenhagen. She adores their design and architecture scene, fashion brands (Stine Goya!), sourdough bread, elderflower juice, and most of all cycling!About Guac: Guac is an award-winning travel publication run by an interdisciplinary group of students at Cornell University. We aim to inspire our readers to celebrate cultural diversity and view the world with an open mind through delivering unique stories from people around the world.Join us on our journey and follow along real-time on our instagram

title: Gelelim kurulumlarına :
content: Furkan DemirelFollowFeb 19 · 3 min readTruffle - Ganache’nin kurulumu ve MyEtherWallet üzerinden işlem yapmaÖncelikle kavramlarımızı tanıyalım.Truffle : Truffle akıllı kontratlarımızı kodlamaya yarayan ve yazılan kodların testini kolaylaştıran Ethereum için bir geliştirici ortamı.Ganache : Ganache bizim için sanal bir Ethereum Blockchain’i yaratır bununla birlikte local ethereum zincirinde adresler açıp bizim yazdığımız kodların testini görmemizi sağlayan bir test ortamıdır.MyEtherWallet : Bir etherum cüzdanı. Kendi local serverımızı MyEtherWallet ile ilişkindirip test ethereum blok zinicirinde işlem yapmamıza olanak saplıyor.Gelelim kurulumlarına :Öncelikle bilgisayaranızda npm’i kurmalıyız.Bilgisayarımızda npm’in kurulu olup olmadığını anlamak için şu kodu yazmanız yeterli olacaktır :npm -vEğer bu işlemden aldığınız görüntü yukarıda ki gibiyse devam edebiliriz. Eğer değilse öncelikle npm kurmalısınız.Daha sonra truffle’ı kuralım :npm install -g truffleGanache :Ganache kurulumu için de benzer bir yolu izliyoruz :npm install -g ganache-cliDaha sonrasında yeni bir klasör oluşturup (mytruffleproject) fikir vermesi açısından hazır bir akıllı kontrat örneği indireceğim.truffle unbox metacoinSonrasında kontratımı compile ediyoruz :truffle compileCompile ettiğimiz kontrarımızı test ediyoruz :truffle testŞu ana kadar ganache’ın sadece kurulumundan bahsettim . İşte tam da burada karşımıza çıkıyor. Ganache’ı kuruduğumuzda bize local ethereum üzerinde çalışan ve hepsinin bakiyesi 100.00 ETH olan 10 tane hesap açtığını göreceksiniz.Oysa yukarıda hesapların birinde bir miktar ether’in azaldığını görüyoruz.Bunun sebebi akıllı kontratımız ile yaptığımız işlemlerden kaynaklı.İşlemlerin detaylarını Blocks kısmından 1 Transaction butonuna tıklayarak görebilirsiniz .Şimdi yaptığımız işlemleri daha iyi anlamak için MyEtherWallet üzerinden örnekler yapalım.Öncelikle MyEtherWallet’ı açıyoruz. Açtıktan sonra Network ETH kısmına gidip “Add Custom Network/Node” a tıklıyoruz.Açılan ekranda Node Name kısmına istediğimiz adı belirliyoruz.URL ve port boşluklarını ise Ganache ana sayfasında ki bilgilerimizle dolduruyoruz. Daha sonra kaydedip kendi node’umuzu oluşturuyoruz.Böylelikle Ganache ile MyEtherWallet’ı ilişkilendirmiş oluyoruz.Şimdide Ganache ve MyEtherWallet’ı ortak olarak kullanıp Ganache’ın bize açtığı local hesaplardan işlemler yapalım.Örneğin ben Ganache’ın açtığı local hesaplarımın birinden diğer hesabıma “50 ETH” göndermek istiyorum. Öncelikle Send Ether&Tokens sayfasını açıyorum.Daha sonra işlemleri onaylıyorum.Burada hangi hesaplar olduğunu ve private key’in nerede olduğunu gösterdim.İşlem gerçekleştikten sonra :Aynı zamdanda Blocks kısmında yeni bir block oluştuğunu da fark edeceksiniz.

title: Truffle or not Truffle? That is the question… or how to seamlessly deploy to ethereum mainnet
content: Truffle or not Truffle? That is the question… or how to seamlessly deploy to ethereum mainnetNicolas CloutierFollowNov 1, 2017 · 3 min readAfter 4 days of deployment nightmare of our new contract with Rob our CTO at Kryptopy Inc, I decided to share our experience with the new Byzantium upgrade of Ethereum, Truffle, Geth, and so on.We wish to share our tips with other blockchain / ethereum developer here to avoid them to relive the same nightmare as we did.First of all, Truffle is a good environment, we like it… for testing. If you want to deploy to mainnet, we definitely not recommend it.The reason is that you will get tons of errors related to the fact that Truffle cannot cope with all the changes and for a reason. There are just too much. So rule #1 use truffle to test your contracts, version them, make sure they work the way they are intended to. But do not use it to deploy.Took us days to understand it. Maybe with the new upgrade that was released today this has changed, however we still wouldn’t use it for that purpose.So first step for a successful contract deployment to Ethereum as of today (October 31st 2017) = Upgrade everything. Old versions simply won’t work with the Byzantium upgrade. This means : geth, parity, and whatever else you are using on a daily basis for your smart contracts. For geth, use version 1.7.2 as a minimum.If you are patient and want to syncronize with geth and do all your deployment from there the old school way, make sure you have plenty of memory and I mean plenty! Less than 16GB of ram and without a decent SSD drive with a lot of space you will run into a lot of problems. Such as the infamous memory leak that is still not fixed (I ran into it again today).Best way to do it?1- Develop your contracts using solidity (latest version) and truffle (yes thats good for that!)2- Test and re-test, if you have a budget make them audited !3- Merge your contracts with a tool like: sol-merger (npm i -g sol-merger)4- Use the online ethereum compiler (https://ethereum.github.io/browser-solidity/)5- Once compiled, click on details, it will give you a javascript with the ABI and Compiled code of your contract.6- You can use parity, contract tab, deploy paste your contract ABI and compiled code, do not forget to tick advanced parameters if you have parameters you need to include (per example wallet address)7- Set your gas, deploy and enjoy !I hope this did save you a lot of headaches!As self promotion phase 2 of Kryptopy Network pre-sale is currently running at https://www.kryptopy.com if you like this article feel free to pitch 0.1ether or more in it :) Thank you for your support in advance.Nick

title: Crazy Problems You’ll See During Truffle Migrations
content: Ah crap — I just wanted some catnip…Crazy Problems You’ll See During Truffle Migrationslee preimesbergerFollowFeb 22, 2018 · 3 min readWoot — yeah. You went through months of work, and you have a bad ass contract you want to send out into the wild (foolishly, if you didn’t test on Rinkeby) or test.Well, you are in for a world of pain brother or sister or whatever name you prefer. Strap yourself in and brace yourself for the top ‘oh crap’ problems you are gonna face.Oh Crap — how do I put this on test/livenet?Ha — it seemed so easy. just do truffle test and magic happens. But you can’t deploy that. The bytecode isn’t available. Even it is was — mist is almost always broken and Ethereum Wallet is even worse. How you actually push this thing out? If you are trying to go directly to livenet you’re not smart. Stop it. I don’t have cut and paste for that just because it’s a bad idea.I’ve say it’s easy, but it’s not. First, you need to start geth locally. By default, truffle is going to start/connect to a temp instance. You need to override that. This is what I use to connect to Rinkeby:geth --fast --rpc --rpcport '9999' --unlock <my wallet address> --password <text file with your passwords> --datadir /home/lpreimesberger/bulk/rinkeby/ --rinkebyObviously — livenet is different because you don’t have the — rinkeby clause. ‘bulk’ points to a large NAS box on my home network. You can skip that point if you don’t use multiple machines or have lots of space in your home directory.You then tell truffle about this by updating truffle.js and truffle-config.js. It’s not clear which is which and I don’t trust what’s there — so I update both:module.exports = {  // See <http://truffleframework.com/docs/advanced/configuration>  // to customize your Truffle configuration!    networks: {        development: {            host: "127.0.0.1",            port: 8545,            network_id: "*" // Match any network id        },        rinkeby: {            host: "127.0.0.1",            port: 9999,            network_id: "4"        }    }};You then have access to deploying to rinkeby with:truffle migrate — network rinkebyOh crap — Expected parameter ‘from’ not passedYeah, this makes zero sense. Everything looks fine — you did everything you’d expect but it doesn’t work.This happens when truffle doesn’t understand which account to use. You need to add a ‘from’ clause to the JSON with the preferred account:module.exports = {  // See <http://truffleframework.com/docs/advanced/configuration>  // to customize your Truffle configuration!    networks: {        development: {            host: "127.0.0.1",            port: 8545,            network_id: "*" // Match any network id        },        rinkeby: {            host: "127.0.0.1",            port: 9999,            network_id: "4",            from: "0x6bF34Aa1a2a9Aa67d5226eF51786938E19f62cD1"        }    }};network_id is the network to use — 4 is reserved for Rinkeby in this case.Oh crap — Error: authentication needed: password or unlocklpreimesberger@dadbuntu:~/projects/takumi$ truffle migration --network rinkebyUsing network 'rinkeby'.Running migration: 1_initial_migration.jsDeploying Migrations...... undefinedError encountered, bailing. Network state unknown. Review successful transactions manually.Error: authentication needed: password or unlockCrap — what does this mean?Ethereum by default locks every account. If you see you are not unlocking the default account that deployment is happening on. Make sure the ‘from’ above references the same account unlocked in geth and the password is right.Oh crap — Bailing — network state unknownThis is infuriating — the symptom is everything looks fine but the contract just craps out and doesn’t work:Running migration: takumi.js  Deploying Migrations...  ... 0xc1dfca48204f704444a31539d83b53c1afc1baaf4e4f55352d31b8c406937178  Migrations: 0x8cdaf0cd259887258bc13a92c0a6da92698644c0Saving successful migration to network...  ... 0x02b8ed4ab56dd0ae7656f99415f968fed333c20b22261193d18b5c07e2468b97Error encountered, bailing. Network state unknown. Review successful transactions manually.Error: unknown transactionThis seems entirely caused by a mismatch between truffle and geth. Ethereum devs tend to make sweeping and breaking changes willy nilly and 1.7-> 1.8 geth is no exception. You usually need to recompile geth from source by going to the source tree from https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum . Clone it and then checkout release/1.7 and build it. Overwrite the geth binary on your system with the downgrade one and this problem will disappear.This problem will probably disappear with an updated truffle — but it will come back.

title: How to Migrate ETH Dapps to ThunderCore using Truffle
content: How to Migrate ETH Dapps to ThunderCore using TruffleKun PengFollowMay 6 · 2 min readIn this tutorial, we will be migrating an existing decentralized application (Dapp) to ThunderCore. We assume that your project has been set up using the popular tool Truffle, though the workflow should be easily adaptable to other tools.Since ThunderCore is compatible with Ethereum, migrating an existing Dapp to ThunderCore is as easy as installing a package and changing a couple of lines in your config.01 Installing dependenciesRun the following command in your project’s root directory (where the contracts directory is located):​npm install truffle-hdwallet-provider web3-provider-engine02 Update Truffle configOpen up truffle.js (or truffle-config.js if you are using Windows) and add the following code to the top of the file:let HDWalletProvider = require(‘truffle-hdwallet-provider’)let mnemonic = “<the mnemonic for your private key>”Note that the mnemonic variable needs to be set to a real mnemonic.Now, in your module exports, include a thunder section under the networks section, like the following:module.exports = {networks: {thunder: {provider: () => HDWalletProvider(mnemonic, “https://testnet-rpc.thundercore.com:8544“),network_id: “*”,gas: 3000000,gasPrice: 50000000000}}}Here you can find a complete example of a valid truffle.js that works with ThunderCore.03 Deploy smart contracts on ThunderCoreTo deploy your smart contracts on ThunderCore, simply run:truffle migrate — network thunderIf you didn’t see any error messages, you should be all set. It was that easy!04 Speed comparison with Ethereum’s Rinkeby TestnetHere is a side-by-side comparison of the same Dapp(the same frontend and same smart contracts) but deployed to Ethereum’s Rinkeby Testnet versus ThunderCore Testnet.Note that smart contracts are only a part of the overall Dapp. For instance, you still need to customize your frontend so that it uses the smart contracts deployed on ThunderCore. We won’t detail the steps here since they are very much dependent on your specific project, but feel free to ask for help in our Discord channel.​A few things to NoteIf your Dapp depends on the block number, it requires a simple change. Contact us for more info at support@thundertoken.com.If your Dapp depends on ChainID, please email us atsupport@thundertoken.comIf your Dapp depends on an external Ethereum contract, please confirm that those contracts have been migrated to ThunderCore first and then update with the Thunder contract address.If the Dapp specifies the Network ID, it needs to be updated to ThunderCore’s Testnet Chain ID/ Network ID is 18 (Refer to the explanation of Chain ID herehttps://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/blob/master/EIPS/eip-155.md)

title: Getting started with Solidity development using Truffle
content: Getting started with Solidity development using TruffleJay PayneFollowJun 29, 2018 · 4 min readUpdated by [Jay Payne] June 28, 2018Updated by Joseph Delong April 9, 2018Presented by Yorke Rhodes January 31, 2017PrerequisitesThe examples shown in this walk-through are done on a GCP preemptive instance running Debian stretchNode.js and the Node Package Manager(npm)Installing these two packages provide the development platform used in this post.commands to install platform packagesSimple Introduction to SolidityInstall and Setup Ethereum Dev and Test EnvironmentInstall truffle and verifyTruffle is the most popular development framework for Ethereum with a mission to make developers life a whole lot easier. Install it by running:sudo npm install -g truffleand then verify it installed correctly by running:truffle.Install ganache-cli and verifyGanache CLI, part of the Truffle suite of Ethereum development tools, is the command line version of Ganache, your personal blockchain for Ethereum development.Ganache CLI uses ethereumjs to simulate full client behavior and make developing Ethereum applications faster, easier, and safer. It also includes all popular RPC functions and features (like events) and can be run deterministically to make development a breeze. Install it by running:sudo npm install -g ganache-cliand then verify that it installed correctly by running:ganache-cliTestRPC was deprecated in favor of ganache-cli and you can use ganache-cli in exactly same way you could previously use TestRPC.Setup to initialize a default truffle projectTo setup the project you need to create an empty directory simplestorage go into it and then create a truffle project inside the empty directory. Create the directory by running mkdir simplestorage then once inside the new directory run truffle init to initialize the new truffle project.The following files and directory structure should be created in the simplestorage directory if the initialization completed successfully.directory listingConfigure truffle to use our ganache-cli clientInside the module.exports section of the truffle.js file the development network needs to be added and following variable set:* host = localhost* port = 8545* network_id = ”*”, // Match any network id* gas = 4600000Copy and Paste this into the modules.export section of truffle.js to add the development network.Create a Solidity ContractThe SimpleStorage smart contract will allow the storage of a favorite number mapped to a specific Ethereum address. This favoriteNumbers mapping will be visible to the public. Create a new file in the contracts directory called SimpleStorage.sol. Copy and paste this code into the new file:SimpleStorage smart contractCompile the new ContractTo compile the SimpleStorage contract run truffle compile in the project’s root directory. It should return various pieces of useful information: * helpful warnings * notifications that a new artifacts has been written.Example of the output of the truffle compile commandLaunch the ganache-cli Ethereum test clientTo test the deployment and the functionality of the contract, start up the ganache-cli Ethereum test client in a second Terminal. It has to be up and running to process the deployment and interactions with the SimpleStorage contract.If you do not have the ability to run a second terminal window you can use screen to create sessions for:* editing project files, run compiles and tests scripts* running the Ethereum test client ganache-cliIn either case the second window or session start the ganache-cli test client by running ganache-cli.Deploy the ContractConfigure truffle to deploy the artifact to the glanache-cli network by creating a new file in the migrations directory called 2_deploy_contracts.js. When we run truffle deploy we should see:* the migration script running* eventually the address of the contract account it was created onTroubleshooting Tip: Make sure you are in the first terminal or screen session.Copy and Paste the following code into the new file:Now run truffle deploy from the root project directory to deploy the SimpleStorage contract. It will be deployed to the test network running in the second terminal window. The output will contain several pieces of useful information such as:network usedcontracts deployedour migration script runningartifacts savedaddress of the contract account.Troubleshooting Tip: if you see any errors check the other terminal or screen session to make sure the test client is running.Testing the ContractEvery contract should be tested before even considering deploying it permanently (on a live ethereum network)! Create a new file in the test directory called simpleStorage.js. Copy and paste the following code into the new file.Test Suite for SimpleStorageRun the TestsTo execute the test script run truffle test.Test resultsThese are the test results. One of the tests failed. Can you find the error, fix it then run the tests again.1 test passes and 1 test failsAfter you find the error and fix it all tests should pass.all tests passTroubleshootingIf you encounter problems, I have a GitHub repository with a working version of this guide. In your terminal run:git clone https://github.com/crashsite/simplestorageIf truffle compile or truffle test fails in the newly cloned folder then there may be an environmental issue. Ensure that NodeJS and NPM are installed correctly.Further Links* Solidity Documentation* Truffle Documentation

title: Upgradeable Contracts: Eternal Storage example using ZeppelinOS and Truffle
content: Upgradeable Contracts: Eternal Storage example using ZeppelinOS and TruffleFugue FoundationFollowOct 29, 2018 · 5 min readRecently returned from the excellent TruffleCon held in Portland, Oregon, I was inspired to tackle a challenging topic that came up on several occasions during the conference. This tutorial is my effort to share my understanding of the eternal storage model, displaying in a step-by-step tutorial that applies the principles and abstractions of upgradeable contracts within a development environment. For proper discussion and depth of these principles, I refer you to the comprehensive articles cited at the end of the tutorial.SetupInstall Truffle (requires Nodejs 5.0+)npm install -g truffleTruffle also requires an Ethereum client to interact with, and for this tutorial I’ll be simply using the built in truffle develop, an interactive console that also spawns a development blockchain for when you don’t need to work with specific accounts.Start by cloning the repo I created for this tutorial. This uses the contracts pulled from ZeppleinOS labs, a repository that holds many strategies, approaches and study cases used to investigate and develop dApps with ZeppelinOS. Well worth looking at the entire code base here, simply amazing work.git clone https://github.com/fuguefoundation/tutorial-eternal-storage.gitcd tutorial-eternal-storagenpm installThe CodeOkay, now that the dev environment is set up, let’s dig into the code. Open the project in your preferred text editor or IDE (I use VS Code and Sublime Text). As I am still wrapping my head around this design principle, again I refer you to the articles below for proper discussion and background. The README in the repo is also helpful to navigate your way through the inheritance structure. What I will add are a few tips and “aha!” moments I discovered along the way, things that may be taken for granted — but are vital to understanding nonetheless — by developers who are experts on this topic. I encourage you to leave comments or feedback as well.For a big picture of the design pattern, come to grips with the idea of separating your data from your logic. In this example, the logic is an ERC20 token.Not all the contracts actually “deploy” (i.e., generate an address) to the blockchain. Look at 2_deploy_contracts.js for more details.Related to the previous point, Proxy.sol is an “abstract contract” and thus can not actually be compiled. It can only serve as a base contract.Pay attention to the inheritance of the logic contracts. Keep track of what functions already exist and which ones are being added or changed.Deploy and interactOk, back in the terminal within the project root directory.trufle compile// You may see some warnings, but this should work finetruffle developtruffle(develop)> migrate// Deploy the contracts: Migrations.sol, EternalStorageProxy, Token_V0, and Token_V1Now let’s establish some helpful variables.truffle(develop)> mainAccount = web3.eth.accounts[0]‘0x627306090abab3a6e1400e9345bc60c78a8bef57’truffle(develop)> transferAccount = web3.eth.accounts[1]‘0xf17f52151ebef6c7334fad080c5704d77216b732’truffle(develop)> tokenV0Address = Token_V0.address‘0xf25186b5081ff5ce73482ad761db0eb0d25abfbf’truffle(develop)> tokenV1Address = Token_V1.address‘0x75c35c980c0d37ef46df04d31a140b65503c0eed’truffle(develop)> eternalAddress = EternalStorageProxy.address‘0xaa588d3737b611bafd7bd713445b314bd453a5c8’Establish that version and implementation are not yet set. These are functions/variables that reside in UpgradeabilityStorage. Notice how the contract is called at the address of EternalStorageProxy.truffle(develop)> UpgradeabilityStorage.at(eternalAddress).implementation.call()‘0x0000000000000000000000000000000000000000’truffle(develop)> UpgradeabilityStorage.at(eternalAddress).version.call()‘’Set version and implementation and confirm. Again, note how one contract is cast by another’s address.truffle(develop)> OwnedUpgradeabilityProxy.at(eternalAddress).upgradeTo(“0”, tokenV0Address, {from: mainAccount}).then(function(result){console.log(result)});truffle(develop)> UpgradeabilityStorage.at(eternalAddress).implementation.call()‘0xf25186b5081ff5ce73482ad761db0eb0d25abfbf’truffle(develop)> UpgradeabilityStorage.at(eternalAddress).version.call()‘0’Now we check that our logic contract is using Eternal Storage. First, we’ll get an instance of Token_V0 contract cast at the EternalStorageProxy address. This allows the variables to persist between updatestruffle(develop)> var token0truffle(develop)> Token_V0.at(eternalAddress).then(function(instance){token0 = instance;})Now we can call functions directly on the contract instance. Let’s first confirm that the account has a zero balance of our token. Then we’ll mint2018 tokens to an account. Then we transfer some of those tokens to another account.truffle(develop)> token0.balanceOf.call(transferAccount)BigNumber { s: 1, e: 0, c: [ 0 ] }truffle(develop)> token0.mint(mainAccount, 2018, {from: mainAccount}).then(function(result){console.log(result)});truffle(develop)> token0.balanceOf.call(mainAccount)BigNumber { s: 1, e: 3, c: [ 2018 ] }truffle(develop)> token0.transfer(transferAccount, 18, {from: mainAccount}).then(function(result){console.log(result)});BigNumber { s: 1, e: 3, c: [ 18 ] }Notice that if we check the balance using an instance of Token_V1 (also cast through the address of EternalStorageProxy) we get the same balance.truffle(develop)> var token1truffle(develop)> Token_V1.at(eternalAddress).then(function(instance){token1 = instance;})truffle(develop)> token1.balanceOf.call(transferAccount)BigNumber { s: 1, e: 0, c: [ 18 ] }Also note that if we try to call any of the added functionality in version 1, we get an error since version 1 is not yet able to write to Eternal Storage.truffle(develop)> token1.finishMinting({from: mainAccount}).then(function(result){console.log(result)});Error: VM Exception while processing transaction: revertUpgrade the logic contractWe’ve already deployed our updated version 1 contract so we’re ready to go. Of course, a more likely workflow would be to deploy an update once you or your team actually come up with these new features. The more you consider these building blocks at the beginning (we are dealing with an immutable ledger after all) the easier such updates should be. Nevertheless, you would deploy the new logic contract using the proper inheritance, in this case, contract Token_V1 is Token_V0. Now update the implementation and version in OwnedUpgradeabilityProxy as before.truffle(develop)> OwnedUpgradeabilityProxy.at(eternalAddress).upgradeTo(“1”, tokenV1Address, {from: mainAccount}).then(function(result){console.log(result)});truffle(develop)> UpgradeabilityStorage.at(eternalAddress).version.call()‘1’Let’s use some of the new functionality in Version 1. Initialize the new logic contract, set the owner, and mint some more tokens. Finally, finish minting.truffle(develop)> token1.initialize(mainAccount, {from:mainAccount}).then(function(result){console.log(result)});truffle(develop)> token1.initialized.call()truetruffle(develop)> token0.mint(mainAccount, 2018, {from: mainAccount}).then(function(result){console.log(result)});truffle(develop)> token0.totalSupply.call()BigNumber { s: 1, e: 3, c: [ 4036 ] }truffle(develop)> token1.totalSupply.call()BigNumber { s: 1, e: 3, c: [ 4036 ] }truffle(develop)> token1.finishMinting({from:mainAccount}).then(function(result){console.log(result)});truffle(develop)> token1.mintingFinished.call()truetruffle(develop)> token1.mint(mainAccount, 2018, {from: mainAccount}).then(function(result){console.log(result)})//error — revert (this will now also revert if you call it on token0 as well)Conclusion and next stepsI hope this was helpful for those (like myself) that are looking to see a more step-by-step approach to upgradeable smart contracts and the eternal storage model specifically. Again, to really understand this tutorial, there is a presumption that you have done the background reading.Next, I plan to make a similar tutorial only using Rootstock and to understand more about how the data layer of upgradeable contracts and storage interact. I’m also considering building on this code to create an Angular frontend and encapsulate it as a Truffle Box, something to give back to these amazing open source projects building the decentralized web. Thanks for reading and following along, see you in the comments!Resources and further readingEternal Storage / Upgradeable contractshttps://blog.zeppelinos.org/smart-contract-upgradeability-using-eternal-storage/https://blog.zeppelinos.org/proxy-patterns/https://blog.colony.io/writing-upgradeable-contracts-in-solidity-6743f0eecc88Abstract contracts (Solidity) and the Template design patternhttps://solidity.readthedocs.io/en/v0.4.25/contracts.html#abstract-contractshttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template_method_patternZeppelinOS labshttps://github.com/zeppelinos/labsTrufflehttps://truffleframework.comAbout Fugue FoundationThe mission of the Fugue Foundation is to alleviate poverty and injustice through the use of decentralized blockchain technology. We are a newly formed nonprofit organization looking for novel ways and partnerships to utilize smart contracts, cryptocurrencies, and the decentralized web to help the less fortunate.
